meeting_annotations.transcript: According to the rules, I cannot be reporter because I was reporter yesterday, so I will back up.

meeting_annotations.speaker: George Weinstock
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, thank you very, very much. That's great. Um, so why don't we go around and just quickly introduce ourselves so we sort of know the range of of disciplines. Uh, um, why don't we start with you, Calvin?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Kaixiong Ye
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, uh, so this is Calvin. I am an assistant professor at the University of Georgia. I'm in the Department of Genetics and my research is uh human genetics. I basically study gene diet interaction in metabolic trade. so in my lab I do a lot of quantitative genetics analysis in like large cohort like UK Bank. My background was actually population genetics. I study how population adapt to the local diet.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Kaixiong Ye
meeting_annotations.transcript: So now I'm doing both.

meeting_annotations.speaker: George Weinstock
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, great. Mark.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Mark Mimee (UChicago)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, yeah, my name is uh Mark. I'm an assistant professor at U Chicago in microbiology and in molecular engineering. And effectively I run a synthetic biology group and we're mostly in the business of engineering and making genetic tools for difficult to engineer um microbes. So uh things that are outside of the realm of like E coli and lactic acid bacteria but more like bacteroides and and bacteria phage as well. Um, so most of the stuff that we do is fairly application driven but we do some some things like, you know, the the project for here, which is a little bit more mechanistic and trying to do some discovery of interactions between uh the microbes and the host with a particular focus on these difficult to engineer microbes.

meeting_annotations.speaker: George Weinstock
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great, thanks. Nandita?

So how the host genes control the composition of the microbiome, how the can the microbiome affect um the host gene regulation and then how this interactions between host genes and the microbiome um affect host health and disease.

meeting_annotations.speaker: George Weinstock
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, great. Tom.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Thomas Mansell
meeting_annotations.transcript: So uh, I am interested in so I'm a chemical engineer. Um, and so my background is is is uh like Mark, I'm also in synthetic biology. Uh, we're interested in more of the model organisms, but our our interest lies really in the environment uh and and manipulating that environment to uh benefit uh a particular organism of interest. So we're interested in live biotherapeutics. So um, the the questions we ask are how can we make a live biotherapeutic which is secreting a small molecule peptide or protein more robust in this environment. And so that is on the genetic level and we are developing some genetic tools in lactic acid bacteria, but also um on the uh at the interface of prebiotics uh and uh probiotics of interest uh feeding them with particularly privileged carbon substrates in order to give them an ecological advantage in that uh in the gut milieu. So that's kind of where I'm at.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ran Blekhman, U of Minnesota (he/him)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think what one question I have whenever I hear about co-evolution is I'm not sure exactly what co-evolution means. Like what's the definition of co-evolution?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ran Blekhman, U of Minnesota (he/him)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Let's say we have like from data.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ran Blekhman, U of Minnesota (he/him)
meeting_annotations.transcript: So we have data, we have like microbiome data and we have host genetic data.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Nandita Garud, UCLA, She/Her
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, I I've I've thought about this and I wonder if uh time series data is necessary.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Nandita Garud, UCLA, She/Her
